10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111641 Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of preparation of the Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst for MS reaction. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 The catalytic performance on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts with different Y2O3 doping amounts in CO2 hydrogenation (a), as well as WTYs of methanol over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 as a function of reaction temperature (b). Reaction condition: V H2/CO2 = 3/1, GHSV = 7200•h − 1, T = 240 °C, P = 3 MPa. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (a) of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images (a, d), TEM (b, e) and HRTEM images (c, f) of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts as well as corresponding metallic Cu particle size distribution (insets of Figs. 3b and 3e). Fig 3 Fig. 4 HAADF-STEM analysis and EDX elemental mappings of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst. Fig 4 Fig. 5 HAADF-STEM analysis and EDX elemental mappings of Cu/ZnO catalyst. Fig 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The Cu 2p (a), Zn 2p (b), Y 3d (c), and O 1 s (d) spectra of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 CO2-TPD (a) and H2-TPD (b) profiles of reduced Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Fig 8 Fig. 9 The WTY of methanol over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation with a time-on-stream of 100 h. Reaction condition: T = 280 °C, P = 3 MPa, m cat = 0.1 g, GHSV = 14,400 h − 1. Fig 9 Table 1 The physical properties and element contents over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Yttria-doped Cu/ZnO catalyst with excellent performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol Tianqinji Qi a Weizuo Li b ⁎ Hong Li a Ke Ji a Shaoyun Chen a Yongchun Zhang a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Department of Catalysis Chemistry and Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning 116024, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals Department of Catalysis Chemistry and Engineering School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China aState Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Department of Catalysis Chemistry and Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning 116024, China b School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213000, China School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213000 China bSchool of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Revealing the origin of the enhanced performance on yttria (Y2O3) promoted Cu/ZnO based catalyst for methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation is still challenging. To shed light upon the promotion effect of Y2O3 modifier on binary Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation reaction, a ternary Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst was synthesized via a citric acid coordination-assisted strategy. The developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst exhibited a remarkably higher Weight-time yeild of methanol (236.8 gMeOH gcat −1∙h − 1) and methanol selectivity (81.1%) in comparison to Cu/ZnO catalyst (159.6 gMeOH gcat −1∙h − 1 and 73.9%, respectively). Various characterizations results have uncovered the enhanced catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis was associated with small size and highly dispersed Cu species and abundant surface adsorption sites as well as more Cu-ZnO interfaces with strong interaction. Moreover, the Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst displayed a superior weight-time yield of methanol with a time-on-stream of 100 h in comparison with classic Cu/ZnO catalyst. We anticipate that this basic design strategy will provide a novel alternative to expand opportunities to explore scalable, cost-effective catalysts for industrial methanol synthesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation to methanol Cu/ZnO catalyst the promotion of yttria 1 Introduction Recently, a great effort was made in direct converting CO2 to high value-added chemicals with H2 produced via water electrolysis using the renewable energy, as a promising and potentially profitable route to relieve the green-house effect possibly brought about the aggravated CO2 emission [1-10]. Industrially, methanol produced by CO hydrogenation [11] is usually used as a chemical feedstock to transform into lower olefins [12,13], high-octane gasoline [14], aromatics [3], and other high-added value chemicals [15-17], and these industrial processes can create a profit to offset the costs of carbon management. In general, an industrial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst was employed to catalyze CO-to-methanol reaction using the syngas (H2/CO2/CO) at moderate pressure (5–10 MPa) and elevated temperature (200–300 °C) [18,19]. Unfortunately, the conventional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst not only exhibits unsatisfying methanol selectivity under CO2 hydrogenation due to generated CO from the reverse water-gas shift reaction, but also suffers from the severe catalyst deactivation caused by poisoning effect of H2O [20-22]. In view of economy efficiency and practical application, it is necessary to develop an efficient catalyst with high methanol selectivity as well as also good stability towards methanol synthesis (MS) reaction. Despite the introduction of Al2O3 greatly improved the catalytic performance of binary Cu/ZnO catalyst towards methanol synthesis from the syngas (i.e., CO and hydrogenation) [23-25], the hydrophilic characteristic of Al2O3 carrier immensely limited Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 application in CO2-to-methanol reaction due to catalyst deactivation induced by in situ generated H2O from MS reaction [21,26]. Generally, some other transition oxide modifiers with their individual characteristics, such as ZrO2 [27-31], In2O3 [32], La2O3 [33,34], CeO2 [35,36], TiO2 [37] and Ga2O3 [38,39], Fe2O3 [40], MnO2 [41] were added to modulate metal Cu dispersion, basicity, surface oxygen vacancies and defect sites, as well as H2 activation capacity of the Cu/ZnO-based catalysts. Except for single component oxide, nanocomposite (e.g., attapulgite/Ce1- x Zr x O2) [40] and carbon [42] evidently boosted the performance of Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation reaction due to the increased number of the strongly basic sites, enhanced Cu surface area as well as surface oxygen defects. Moreover, the structure of precursors [43,44] and compositions [45,46], which were also considerably correlated with the dispersion of the active species via controlling reaction conditions to improve catalytic performance. In addition, as for La2CuO4 perovskite, an active material for methanol synthesis, derived from La-Cu-Zn-O precursor by changing the calcination temperature contributed to improving methanol selectivity [47]. Recently, the low-cost yttrium oxide (Y2O3), a promising promoter, greatly enhanced metal Cu dispersion and the reducibility of CuO species on the multicomponent Cu/ZnO/ZrO2/Ga2O3/Y2O3 catalyst exhibiting the superior catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation [48]. Moreover, Y2O3 dopants incorporated into Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst can inhibit the agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles in reduction and reaction processes [27,49]. At present, the investigations on Y2O3-containing Cu/ZnO based catalysts mainly focus on the multicomponent system (e.g., Cu/ZnO/Al2O3/Y2O3, Cu/ZnO/ZrO2/Y2O3, or Cu/ZnO/ZrO2/Ga2O3/Y2O3), the Y2O3 promoter on the structural and surface characteristics of catalysts often suffers from the interaction effect derived from other modifiers. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the influence of Y2O3 promoter on the microstructure of Cu and ZnO phases, and on Cu-ZnO synergetic effect. In this study, we focus on revealing the origin of enhanced catalytic performance in ternary Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst. The Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst was synthesized via a citric acid (CA) coordination-assisted method (Scheme 1 ). Briefly, self-assemably reaction (a) at 60 °C affords a porous metal citrate gel (b) regarded as the catalyst precursor. The resulting catalyst was obtained by the calcination of the metal citrate gel in air (c), followed by the reduction process under flowing H2/N2 (d). In order to reveal the origin of enhanced catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, various characterizations including powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2 and H2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD and H2-TPD, respectively) and N2O dissociative adsorption experiment were employed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All metal nitrates [Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O and Y(NO3)3∙6H2O] purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd with 99.9% purity were used in this work. CA powder was purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd with 99% purity. 2.2 The synthesis of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts were prepared by the CA coordination-assisted method. For 5 mol% Y2O3-doped Cu/ZnO catalyst, the Zn/Cu molar ratio was fixed at 4, and the molar ratio of Y/(Cu + Zn) was fixed at 5 mol%. Typically, for Cu/ZnO/Y2O3, 1.2 M CA aqueous solution and 1.0 M metallic nitrates salts aqueous solution consisting of Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O (2.44 g, 10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O (12.02 g, 40 mmol), and Y(NO3)3∙6H2O (0.96 g, 5 mmol) were simultaneously added into 50 mL deionized water, and then held for 4 h under vigorous stirring at 60 °C. The resulting sol was kept at 60 °C under a vacuum for the removal of water until the formation of a dark-blue gel. The gel was placed in an oven at 110 °C for 48 h. The dried precursor was calcined under a static air at 450 °C for 4 h, and the resulting catalyst was denoted as Cu/ZnO/Y2O3. For binary Cu/ZnO catalyst, the dosages of nitrates and CA powder, as well as the preparation procedure are similar to that of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst except that Y(NO3)3∙6H2O was not used. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns of as-prepared catalysts were recorded on a powder X-ray diffractometer (D/max-2400, Rigaku Corp.). ICP-AES was carried out on an AVIO 500 instrument (Perkinelmer, Inc.). TGA-DSC was performed on a DSC instrument (Mettle Toledo, Int. Inc.) equipped with a mass spectrometer (QMS200, Pfeiffer). FT-IR spectra were collected using an EQUINOX55 spectrometer (Bruker Corp.). N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured on an Autosorb-1-MP instrument (Quantachrome Co. Ltd). FESEM measurement was performed using a Nova Nano SEM 450 instrument (FEI Corp.). TEM measurement was obtained using a JEM-F200 TEM instrument (JEOL Ltd). XPS measurement was performed on ESCA LAB250 instrument (Thermo VG) using an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) source. The binding energy was calibrated by using adventitious carbon (C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV). H2-TPR, CO2-TPD and H2-TPD experiments were carried out on a chemisorption instrument (FINETEC, FINESORB-3010H) (more detailed procedure described in the Supporting Information). Cu dispersion (D Cu) and metallic Cu special surface area (S Cu) were determined by dissociative N2O chemisorption experiment (the detailed displayed in the Supporting Information). 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic activity test of the catalysts was performed in a self-built fixed bed reactor equipped with an inner stainless-steel tube (8 mm O.D.). Before the activity test, 100 mg catalyst diluted with quartz sand (20–40 mush) was firstly pre-reduced under diluted H2 flow (10% H2/90% N2, 50 mL∙min−1) at 250 °C for 2 h. The pre-reduced procedure was performed under atmospheric pressure. After that, reduced catalyst was purged with pure N2 until the temperature dropped to reaction temperature. Then, pure N2 was switched to flowing feed gas (H2/CO2=3/1, 12 mL∙min−1) and the pressure was elevated to 3 MPa. The activity test was started under different temperatures (220, 240, 260, 280, and 300 °C, respectively). The effluent products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (FULI, GC-9790) equipped with a TCD detector. The conversion of CO2 ( X C O 2 ) and methanol selectivity ( S C H 3 OH ) were calculated using an internal normalization method, which was calculated using Eqs. (4) and 5: (4) X CO 2 ( % ) = 100 × n CO 2 in − n CO 2 out n CO 2 in (5) S CH 3 OH ( % ) = 100 × n CH 3 OHout n CO 2 in − n CO 2 out The WTY of methanol was defined as the mass of methanol generated per gram catalyst per hour and calculated as follows: (6) WTY ( g CH 3 OH · kg cat − 1 · h − 1 ) = F CO 2 × X CO 2 × S CH 3 OH × M CH 3 OH 22400 × m cat Where F CO2 represents the flow rate of influent CO2 (mL∙min−1), M CH3OH was the methanol relative molecule mass (g∙mol−1), m cat stands for the catalyst mass (g). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation Fig. 1 a exhibits the catalytic performance of the Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts prepared with different contents of Y2O3 for hydrogenation of CO2. As depicted in Fig. 1a, it can be observed that the contents of Y2O3 have obvious effect on the CO2 conversion (X CO2), methanol selectivity (S CH3OH) and WTY of methanol of as-prepared catalysts for hydrogenation of CO2 reaction. A monotonic increase in X CO2, S CH3OH and WTY of methanol was observed with increasing Y2O3 loading from 0 wt% to 5 mol%. Beyond 5 mol%, X CO2, S CH3OH and WTY of methanol gradually decrease as Y2O3 loading was increased from 10 mol% to 15 mol%. Therefore, 5 mol% Y2O3 was the optimized loading amount. Moreover, the performance over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts was investigated at different reaction temperatures. It can be observed that the WTYs of methanol over two catalysts went up with ascending temperatures (from 220 to 260 °C) then dropped down with the elevated temperatures (from 260 to 300 °C), and the highest WTY of methanol was obtained at 260 °C (Fig. 1b). The X CO2 goes up while the S CH3OH decreases with increasing reaction temperature from 220 to 300 °C (Fig. S8), which is due to the inherent characteristic of MS reaction as an exothermic reaction ( Δ r H ( 298 K ) = −49.5 kJ∙mol−1) versus the endothermic RWGS reaction ( Δ r H ( 298 K ) = 41.2 kJ∙mol−1) [50,51]. More importantly, the Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst exhibited the superior catalytic performance compared with that with Cu/ZnO catalyst in the whole temperature region, further indicating the promotion effect of Y2O3 doping on methanol synthesis. In order to uncover the origin of enhanced catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, various characterization techniques were performed. 3.2 The structural and morphological characterization XRD analysis was carried out to gain insights into the effect of Y2O3 doping on structural variation of the catalyst, and corresponding structural parameters were listed in Table S1. As shown in Fig. 2 , the main diffraction peaks on two reduced catalysts, located at 43.4° and 50.5°, were assigned to characteristic (111) and (200) planes of cubic Cu phase (JCPDS-04–0836). Three sharp diffraction peaks on two reduced catalysts, centered at 31.5°, 34.5°, and 36.3°, were indexed as diagnostic (100), (002) and (101) planes of ZnO phase (JCPDS-36–1451). No diffraction peak was assigned to Y2O3 phase on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3, indicating that Y2O3 species as amorphous phase were dispersed in ZnO matrix (Fig S3 and Fig. S5, as well as more details were given in supporting information). The Cu and ZnO diffraction peaks over Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst shifted to higher angles (Fig. 2 inset), and their full width at half maximum (FWHM) became broadened (Table S1) in comparison with those of Cu/ZnO catalyst, suggesting that Y2O3 doping may enhance the dispersity of Cu and ZnO species and/or decrease their particle sizes. The lattice constants of ZnO (a ZnO and c ZnO) in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst are slightly smaller than those of Cu/ZnO catalyst (Table S1). That might be explained by the substitution of larger Zn2+ ion (0.6 Å) in ZnO lattice by smaller ionic radius of Cu2+ ion (0.57 Å) [52]. Moreover, it was worth noting that the larger decrease in the crystal size in ZnO (d ZnO) (from 20.0 to 10.0 nm) after Y2O3 doping into Cu/ZnO, in comparison with that of metal Cu (d Cu) (from 24.1 to 20.3 nm), which suggested that Y2O3 doping had a more vital role in the structure variation of ZnO species than in metal Cu. Furthermore, to confirm the above-mentioned speculation (partial Y2O3 species may incorporate into ZnO lattice), XRD analysis of pure ZnO and binary ZnO/Y2O3 samples prepared with the same preparation method was performed (Fig. S4). All diffraction peaks over the two samples were assigned to hexagonal ZnO phase. The absence of Y2O3 characteristic peaks were possibly due to low Y2O3 concentration or uniformly distributed in ZnO matrix. The main diffraction peaks of hexagonal ZnO on ZnO/Y2O3 slightly shifted to lower angles compared with those of pure ZnO sample, and the FWHM value evidently decreased after Y2O3 doping. In addition, the lattice parameters of over two samples were listed in Table S1. The larger lattice parameters of ZnO phase (a ZnO and c ZnO) on ZnO/Y2O3 sample in comparison with pure ZnO suggest that larger Y3+ ions (0.92 Å) substitutes Zn2+ ions (0.74 Å) in the ZnO lattice. All of which suggested that partial Y2O3 species were incorporated into ZnO lattice. Fig. 3 displays the morphology and metallic Cu particle size distribution on the reduced Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. Both of two reduced catalysts exhibited several micrometers of aggregation made up of large quantities of particles, accompanied by the appearance of many holes and caves among these particles (Figs. 3a and d). The formed holes and caves resulted from the decomposition of catalyst precursor during the calcination process, which is good for the transportation of reactants and products under the reaction process. Moreover, Fig. 3b and Fig. 3e depict TEM images of the two reduced catalysts as well as corresponding histograms of metallic Cu particle size distribution (seen in insets). As for TEM image of Cu/ZnO catalyst, many agglomerated Cu nanoparticles were observed (Fig. 3b), and the average particle size of metallic Cu nanoparticles was approximate 26 nm (inset in Fig. 3b). As comparison to Cu/ZnO catalyst, it can be observed that Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst shows more dispersive morphology (Fig. 3e) and the smaller size (14.6 nm) metallic Cu nanoparticles. The nanostructures of Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts were investigated by HRTEM. As presented in Fig. 3c, Cu/ZnO catalyst shows two distinct lattice fringes of 0.210 and 0.281 nm, which corresponded to characteristic Cu (111) and ZnO (100) planes, respectively. Moreover, it can be observed that the bulky metallic Cu nanoparticle with a size of more than 30 nm separates from the adjacent ZnO nanoparticle (with a size of ~ 30 nm). As depicted in Fig. 3f, two clear lattice fringes of 0.181 and 0.281 nm on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst were assigned to metal Cu (200) and ZnO (100) planes, respectively. Moreover, it can be seen that Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst presents the compacted nanostructure as well as affluent overlapped Cu-ZnO interfaces. It could be speculated that the formation of Cu-ZnO interface is attributed to the close contact between small size of metallic Cu and ZnO nanoparticles, which is consistent with above XRD and TEM results (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3f). Therefore, the doping of Y2O3 can facilitate the formation of overlapped Cu-ZnO interface and strengthen the interaction between metal Cu and ZnO. HAADF-STEM analysis coupled with EDX elemental mapping was carried out to investigate the elements distribution on Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts. As for HAADF image of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst (Fig. 4 ), it can be seen that approximate 20 nm of nanoparticles showed clear particle edges and a slight agglomeration. Corresponding elemental mappings also showed homogeneous distribution for all elements, especially Cu element, which indicates that Y2O3 doping has a beneficial for homogeneous distribution of elements on the surfaces of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst. For HAADF mapping of Cu/ZnO catalyst, the aggregated and large particles were observed. Moreover, elemental mappings exhibited the aggregated distributions for Cu and Zn elements (Fig. 5 ), suggesting the agglomeration for Cu and Zn species in the absence of Y2O3 dopant. As compared to Cu/ZnO catalyst, it can be speculated that the homogeneous element distribution in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst is associated with the substitution of Zn2+ sites in ZnO lattice with Cu2+ ion caused by Y2O3 doping, which is in agreement with XRD results. 3.3 The Cu-ZnO synergetic effect H2-TPR was performed to investigate the reducibility of CuO species and Cu-ZnO synergetic effect. As presented in Fig. 6 , two reduction peaks on pure CuO, located at 200 °C and 225 °C, are assigned to the reduction of dispersive CuO species and bulk CuO, respectively. As compared to pure CuO, two main reduction peaks on Cu/ZnO catalyst shifted to lower temperature (193 and 203 °C, respectively), which can be explained by the dispersion effect of ZnO on CuO. For Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, the reduction peak of CuO species shifted to higher temperature (239 °C) even higher than that of pure CuO, suggesting the strong metal support interaction (SMSI) between Cu and ZnO. The interacted Cu species featured with small crystal size but difficult to be reduced are possibly derived from either dispersed CuO species embedded in ZnO matrix [53] or CuO species closely contacting with ZnO at CuO/ZnO interfaces [54], which were confirmed by TEM image (Fig. S7). Moreover, Raman spectrum was also conducted to further reveal the promotion effect led by the formation of the oxygen vacancy resulted from the Y2O3 doping. As shown in Fig. S6, the peaks at ~320, ~430 and ~570 cm−1 over the two catalysts were ascribed to 2E2 (low), E2 (high) and A1 (LO) modes of ZnO, respectively. For Raman spectrum of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, the Raman peaks corresponding to E2 and A1 modes of ZnO shifted to lower shifts, which are ascribed to the size effect of ZnO caused by Y2O3 doping. For Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, the presence of a remarkable characteristic peak (569 cm−1), which is associated with the generated oxygen vacancy in ZnO lattice led by the Y2O3 doping, which is consistent with previous reported work [55]. The H2-TPR and Raman analysis have demonstrated that Y2O3 doping could improve the interaction between Cu and ZnO. XPS analysis was performed to uncover chemical states of surface species of the catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 7 a, Cu 2p spectra exhibits typical Cu 2p core peaks located at ~932 and ~952 eV on two catalysts, which are assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks of metal Cu0 species, respectively [56]. Interestingly, Cu 2p3/2 peak on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 (932.0 eV) in contrast to Cu/ZnO (932.2 eV) shifted to the lower binding energy (BE) value, indicating an increased electron density of surface Cu species of the former. That can be explained by the existence of charge transfer from ZnO to metal Cu [57]. Besides, Fig. 7b displays Zn 2p peaks of two reduced catalysts, centered at ~1021 and ~1044 eV, which corresponded to the Zn 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks of Zn2+ species in bulk ZnO, respectively [58]. As compared to Cu/ZnO catalyst, an up-shift to higher BE values towards Zn 2p peaks in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst was observed, further suggesting the existence of charge transfer from ZnO to metal Cu. The strong metal-support interaction between Cu and ZnO is supported by the appearance of the opposite shifts of BE values in Cu 2p and Zn 2p peaks of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst. Fig. 7c shows Y 3d spectrum of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst in the BE value range of 152–165 eV. As can be seen here, two characteristic peaks, located at 157.6 and 159.6 eV, were attributed to Y 3d5/2 and Y 3d3/2 peaks of Y(OH)3 , respectively [59]. Basic hydroxyl groups of surface Y(OH)3 species can strengthen CO2 adsorption process by the formation of carbonate species, accompanying with the increased CO2 adsorption amount [60]. Moreover, surface oxygen species of two reduced catalysts were identified by O 1 s spectra (Fig. 7d). As depicted in Fig. 7d, the peaks on two catalysts, located at ~530, ~531, and ~532 eV, were attributed to lattice oxygen species (OL), surface hydroxyl groups (OOH), and other weakly bound oxygen species (Oad), respectively [61,62]. Notably, in comparison with Cu/ZnO, the slightly lower binding energy of lattice oxygen contained in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts made the electrons easily excited from ZnO support, which further may facilitate the electron transfer at the Cu-ZnO interface, resulting in the generation of more oxygen vacancies, which was in consistent with Raman analysis. The surface composition and the distribution of oxygen species were summarized in Table 3. It can be seen that the surface contents of Cu and Zn elements decreased, which was possibly due to dilution effect of Y2O3 doping. Moreover, the developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst had a larger surface Zn/Cu ratio (10.3) in comparison with that with Cu/ZnO (8.2), suggesting the strong interaction between Cu and ZnO leading to a partial coverage of the Cu surface with ZnO x and generating more Cu-ZnO interfaces under reducing conditions, which is consistent with HRTEM analysis and reported literature [19,23]. Moreover, the surface contents of Cu and Zn elements over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts were analyzed by the TEM-EDS. As displayed in Table S2, for Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, the surface Cu content (8.8 wt%) was remarkably lower than that of Cu/ZnO catalyst (23.6 wt%), which is also lower than the bulk Cu content measured by ICP (14.6 wt%), indicating that surface Cu species either migrates into ZnO matrix or substitutes Zn sites in ZnO lattice. Moreover, the results of reduction degrees measured by single pulse experiments over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts were 0.69 and 0.61 (Table S2), respectively. It was also suggested that migration of surface Cu species with strong Cu-ZnO x interaction leading to a partial coverage of the Cu surface with ZnO x under reducing conditions on Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 in comparison to Cu/ZnO. More importantly, in contrast to Cu/ZnO catalyst, the larger content for lattice oxygen species (OL) in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst indicates that the formation of a larger quantity of Cu-ZnO interfaces since the content of Cu-ZnO interface is associated with the content of lattice oxygen content [63]. The lattice oxygen species correlated with the content of Cu-ZnO interface sites was ascribed to that the lattice oxygen is responsible for electrons transfer from the conductive band of ZnO to the Fermi level of metal Cu, which also facilities the formation of oxygen vacancies [62]. The generated oxygen vacancies were beneficial for charge transfer, leading to the rearrangement of electrons at the Cu/ZnO interface, which also modified the structural and electronic interactions between Cu and vacancies on ZnO, thus leading to the increased Cu-ZnO interaction [64]. 3.4 CO2 and H2 adsorption properties To explore the capacity of activating CO2 and H2 molecules on two catalysts, CO2-TPD and H2-TPD experiments were performed. As presented in Fig. 8 a, CO2-TPD curves are deconvoluted into three desorption peaks (α, β, and γ peaks, respectively) to gain insight into surface adsorption sites for CO2 molecules. The low-temperature desorption peak, located at ~120 °C, was attributed to CO2 desorption from weakly basic sites, which were originated from the hydroxyl groups on the surface [65]. The desorption peaks centered at ~200 and ~310 °C were assigned to CO2 desorption from the moderately basic sites and the strongly basic sites, respectively. The moderately basic sites were associated with metal-oxygen pairs (such as Zn-O, Y-O), and the strongly basic sites were ascribed to coordinatively unsaturated O2− ions on catalyst surface [27,29]. The maximal desorption temperature towards all desorption peaks has no obvious changes, which indicates that Y2O3 dopant has no impact on the basicity strength of catalyst. Moreover, the amounts of CO2 desorption from each basic site of two catalysts were summarized in Table 2. CO2 desorption amount towards α peak (13.4 μmol/g) in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 is nearly three times as that of Cu/ZnO catalyst (5.0 μmol/g), indicating a larger number of weakly basic sites (Table 2). It means that the doping of Y2O3 gives rise to more surface hydroxyl groups. Besides, CO2 desorption amount for β peak (28.4 μmol/g) in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 is five times higher than that of Cu/ZnO catalyst (5.0 μmol/g), suggesting a much higher quantity of metal-oxygen pairs on the surface. All of which suggested that Y2O3 doping promoted more dispersive ZnO species formed on the surface. More importantly, it also can be observed that the presence of γ peak with high amount of CO2 desorption (13.3 μmol/g) in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst, indicating that the formation of more coordinatively unsaturated O2− ions on the surface. These oxygen species were produced to compensate the positive charge generated by a cationic vacancy due to the incorporation of Y3+ ions into the ZnO lattice [66]. Moreover, the intermediates (e.g., formate, methoxyl) adsorbed on strongly basic sites that prefers to be hydrogenated to methanol rather than those on weakly or moderately basic sites [67,68,27]. Correlated with above catalytic selectivity and characterizations results, the developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 exhibits higher methanol selectivity for MS reaction than that in Cu/ZnO catalyst was ascribed to the adsorbed species (e.g., CO2, bicarbonates and unidentate carbonates) on the weakly and moderately basic sites with low desorption temperature may easily dissociate to form CO rather than methanol, whereas the opposite correlation with the strongly basic sites to the total basic site [27,68]. To compare the ability to activate H2 towards two catalysts, the H2-TPD experiments were carried out on Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts at temperatures ranging from 20 to 500 °C. The H2-TPD curves were deconvoluted into two desorption peaks which were denoted by α and β peaks, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8b, α peak nearly at ~130 °C was assigned to desorption of atomic hydrogen on surface Cu sites, and the broad β peak at ~230 °C was attributed to the desorption of hydrogen strongly absorbed either on bulk Cu particles or ZnO surface [69]. In particular, desorbed H2 from ZnO probably originates from the heterolytic split (Hδ+ - Hδ−) of H2 induced by the “p-type” semiconductor behavior of ZnO [70]. Notably, a down-shift in desorption temperature towards α peak in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 in contrast to Cu/ZnO catalyst was observed, which indicates that there is a smaller value for the activation energy of H2 desorption from surface Cu adsorption sites [71]. In addition, the desorption temperature for β peak in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 shifted to higher temperature in comparison to Cu/ZnO catalyst, implying the higher activation energy of H2 desorption on ZnO surface. The measured H2 desorption amounts for two catalysts were listed in Table 2. Hydrogen desorption amount towards α peak in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst (18.6 μmol/g) were strikingly larger than that of Cu/ZnO catalyst (1.1 μmol/g), indicating that Y2O3 doping leads to a much larger amount of surface Cu sites, which has been confirmed S Cu value (Table 1 ). Besides, a nearly 20-fold increase in H2 desorption amount for β peak in Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 (14.3 μmol/g) as comparison to Cu/ZnO catalyst (0.8 μmol/g) was found, suggesting the formation of more surface Zn sites or Cu-ZnO interfaces of the former, which might be due to strong H2 spillover effect driven by the strengthened Cu-ZnO synergetic effect due to Y2O3 doping [70]. Since ZnO as a reservoir can store H atoms, abundant surface Zn sites enable to provide sufficient H atoms for hydrogenation of the intermediates. 3.5 The WTY of methanol with time-on-stream (TOS) Fig. 9 depicts the WTYs of methanol over Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts under certain reaction conditions during MS reaction with a TOS of 100 h. It is worth noting that the developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst exhibited a comparatively higher catalytic stability (WTY of methanol from 359.2 to 323.2 gMeOH kgcat −1 h − 1) in contrast to Cu/ZnO catalyst (from 304.2 to 230.4 gMeOH kgcat −1 h − 1) during 100 h TOS, suggesting that the doped Y2O3 can efficiently enhance the catalytic performance. Conclusions A ternary Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst was prepared via a CA molecule coordination-assisted strategy to investigate the promotion effect of Y2O3 on Cu/ZnO system for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The decomposition behavior of the catalyst precursor was investigated by TGA-MS analysis. Importantly, it is found that Y2O3 doping greatly improves the reaction activity and catalytic stability of Cu/ZnO catalyst for methanol synthesis over 100 h TOS stability test. The role of Y2O3 doping on the structural and electronic characteristics of Cu/ZnO catalyst was investigated by various characterization techniques. The results have revealed that the introduction of Y2O3 facilitates substitution of Zn2+ sites contained in ZnO by Cu2+ ions and reduces crystal sizes of Cu and ZnO, thereby generating more highly dispersed Cu and ZnO species and Cu-ZnO interfaces as well as more coordinatively unsaturated O2− species. All of which are responsible for the improved catalytic activity and methanol selectivity of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis reaction. We anticipated that the developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst prepared by the coordination-assisted strategy may be an industrial catalyst for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. coredata.dc:description: Revealing the origin of the enhanced performance on yttria (Y2O3) promoted Cu/ZnO based catalyst for methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation is still challenging. To shed light upon the promotion effect of Y2O3 modifier on binary Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation reaction, a ternary Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst was synthesized via a citric acid coordination-assisted strategy. The developed Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst exhibited a remarkably higher Weight-time yeild of methanol (236.8 gMeOH gcat −1∙h − 1) and methanol selectivity (81.1%) in comparison to Cu/ZnO catalyst (159.6 gMeOH gcat −1∙h − 1 and 73.9%, respectively). Various characterizations results have uncovered the enhanced catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis was associated with small size and highly dispersed Cu species and abundant surface adsorption sites as well as more Cu-ZnO interfaces with strong interaction. Moreover, the Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalyst displayed a superior weight-time yield of methanol with a time-on-stream of 100 h in comparison with classic Cu/ZnO catalyst. We anticipate that this basic design strategy will provide a novel alternative to expand opportunities to explore scalable, cost-effective catalysts for industrial methanol synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Yttria-doped Cu/ZnO catalyst with excellent performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
